p.s: Description of Pasteurella bettii sp. nov.

Pasteurella bettii (betti'i. M.L. gen. n. bettii, of Bett, named for a gentleman named Bett [Catalog of Strains, 8th ed., American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Md., 19681, whose identity has not been traced)
Phenon 13 of Sneath and Stevens (46); “Pasteurella sp. bettii” of Kilian et al. (22), Cells are small nonmotile bacilli and coccobacilli that are often <1 μm long.
Growth is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, mesophilic.

Surface colonies grown aerobically on sheep blood agar are round, greyish, semitransparent, about 2 mm in diameter after 48 h at 37°C, and without hemolysis but sometimes with greening of the erythrocytes.
Notable for fermenting carbohydrates slowly and weakly, for not acidifying galactose, and for giving negative oxidase and urease reactions (46).
Other properties are shown in Table 2.
Isolated from human Bartholin gland abscesses and human finger infections (Catalog of Strains, 8th ed., American Type Culture Collection).
Phenotypically similar to P. ureae and A. actinomycetemcomitans (46).

DNA-DNA pairing values of 20 to 40% have been reported to a number of Pasteurella species and to Haemophilus parainfluenzae (28, 33, but values of less than 10% have been reported to P. ureae and species of the genus Actinobacillus(13).
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 38.6 mol% (Tm method) (28).
The type strain is strain NCTC 10535 (= ATCC 23273 = CDC 41-5568 = A99 and A271 = 50) (28, 46).
In our hands this strain was positive for the tests marked d in Table 2, except for acid production from maltose.
